choices.text: It blocks both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors
It acts as directly acting arterial vasodilator resulting in indirect effect of tachycardia
It primarily acts as venodilator with little effect on arterioles
It decreases peripheral vascular resistance by directly acting as relaxant of vascular smooth muscle

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct regarding the mechanism of action of labetalol? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It blocks both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors

 

  • Labetalol is a 3rd generation beta blocker having the property of additional α and β blockade.

  • α1 receptor blockade leads to the relaxation of arterial smooth muscle and leads to vasodilation, The beta 1 blockade also contributes to a fall in blood pressure as it blocks reflex sympathetic stimulation of the heart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B It acts as directly acting arterial vasodilator resulting in indirect effect of tachycardia: Is direct acting vasodilators like hydralazine and minoxidil.

 

Option C. It primarily acts as venodilator with little effect on arterioles: Could be nitrates because they cause primarily venodilation.

 

Option D It decreases peripheral vascular resistance by directly acting as relaxant of vascular smooth muscle: Is the property of vasodilators.

choices.text: This action can be reversed by phenylephrine.
﻿﻿﻿It cannot be reversed by levallorphan.
﻿﻿﻿It is caused by activation of the Edinger-Westphal nucleus.
﻿﻿﻿Tolerance develops to this adverse effect on long-term use.

questions.text: A patient with a history of substance addiction is admitted to the hospital due to the overdose of the addictive substance. The patient has slow heart rate, respiratory depression, and low blood pressure. His ocular findings are shown below. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is caused by activation of the Edinger-Westphal nucleus.
 

The pupil is constricted in the given image and as the history describes the patient to be an addict, who is brought to the hospital in an intoxicated state. The clinical features like pin-point pupils, bradycardia, hypotension, respiratory depression suggests that this is a case of opioid intoxication.


Opioid induced miosis:

 

  • The pupillary constriction caused by opioids result due to the activation of the Edinger Westphal Nucleus. Therefore, topical use of opioids in the eye does not induce miosis. It will be seen only on systemic administration of opioids.
  • The miosis induced by opioids cannot be reversed by mydriatic drugs like phenylephrine or anticholinergic drugs. Rather it can be reversed by opioid antagonists like naloxone and levallorphan.
  • Tolerance does not develop to opioid induced miosis even on long term use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. This action can be reversed by phenylephrine: Phenylephrine is a mydriatic agent that causes dilation of the pupil by stimulating alpha-1 adrenergic receptors. It would not reverse opioid-induced miosis, which is due to central nervous system effects rather than direct effects on the iris muscles.

 

Option B. It cannot be reversed by levallorphan: Levallorphan is an opioid antagonist that can reverse the effects of opioid toxicity, including miosis. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

 

Option D. Tolerance develops to this adverse effect on long-term use: Tolerance to opioid-induced miosis does not typically develop, even with long-term use of opioids. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Opioid-induced miosis is caused by activation of the Edinger-Westphal nucleus, and it is a characteristic sign of opioid intoxication. This effect cannot be reversed by phenylephrine, and tolerance does not develop to this effect with long-term opioid use. Opioid antagonists like naloxone and levallorphan can reverse the miosis caused by opioid overdose

questions.text: Which among the following drugs is the new FDA approved immune check point inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pembrolizumab

 

The new FDA-approved immune checkpoint inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium is Pembrolizumab.

 

Pembrolizumab is a monoclonal antibody against PD-1 receptor (Programmed Death Receptor) that can be used for many cancers including endometrial carcinoma. Some of the other cancers where it is useful are:

 

  • Metastatic urothelial cancer
  • Refractory melanoma
  • Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Merkel cell cancer
  • Chemotherapy Refractory Head and Neck Cancer

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nivolumab: is an immune checkpoint inhibitor that acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor - 1 (PD-1) and is used for the treatment of advanced melanoma and relapsed/refractory classical Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option C. Trastuzumab: is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits the HER2 receptor. It is used in the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer.

 

Option D. Ipilimumab: is a monoclonal antibody that binds to cytotoxic T lymphocyte-associated Protein 4 (CTLA-4) and is approved for the treatment of late-stage melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pembrolizumab is the new FDA-approved immune checkpoint inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium. It works by blocking the PD-1 receptor, enhancing the immune system's ability to attack cancer cells. It is also used for treating several other cancers, including metastatic urothelial cancer, refractory melanoma, Hodgkin’s lymphoma, Merkel cell cancer, and chemotherapy-refractory head and neck cancer.

choices.text: 2-10 mcg/kg/min
< 2 mcg/kg/min
10-20 mcg/kg/min

questions.text: The dose at which dopamine acts on beta 1 receptors is:(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2-10 mcg/kg/min

 

2-10 mcg/kg/min is the correct dose range at which dopamine primarily acts on beta 1 receptors in the heart, enhancing cardiac output by increasing heart rate and contractility.

 

Dopamine acts upon 3 receptors depending upon the dose:

 

D1 – < 2 mcg/kg/min (Present in the blood vessels of the kidney in highest concentration - Vasodilation and increased renal blood flow)

 

β1 – 2-10 mcg/kg/min (Present in the heart - Increased heart rate and contractility, which improves cardiac output)

 

α1 – >10 mcg/kg/min (Present in blood vessels - Vasoconstriction, which increases blood pressure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. < 2 mcg/kg/min: At this dose, dopamine primarily acts on D1 receptors, causing vasodilation and increased renal blood flow without significant effects on the heart.

 

Option C. 10-20 mcg/kg/min: At this higher dose, dopamine acts predominantly on alpha 1 receptors, causing vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure.

 

Option D. > 20 mcg/kg/min: Similar to the previous option, at doses higher than 20 mcg/kg/min, dopamine continues to exert effects primarily on alpha 1 receptors, resulting in significant vasoconstriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dopamine has dose-dependent receptor selectivity. It acts on beta 1 receptors at doses of 2-10 mcg/kg/min, increasing cardiac output by enhancing heart rate and contractility.

choices.text: Increase the dose
Decrease the dose
Stop the drug
Stop retigabine and start on carbamazepine

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with epilepsy was put on retigabine thrice a day. Now phenytoin is being added. Which of the following changes should be made to retigabine therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Increase the dose

 

In the scenario where phenytoin is added to a patient's epilepsy treatment regimen that already includes retigabine, and if one of the provided options must be chosen, the most appropriate choice, based on known pharmacological interactions, would be:

 

  • The rationale for this choice is based on the enzyme-inducing properties of phenytoin. Phenytoin is known to induce hepatic enzymes that metabolize many drugs, potentially leading to reduced levels of these drugs. The general principle of enzyme induction suggests that the levels of retigabine could be decreased when phenytoin is added. Therefore, an increase in the dose of retigabine may be necessary to maintain therapeutic drug levels and effective seizure control.
  • However, it's important to emphasize that any dose adjustment should be made cautiously and based on clinical monitoring, including assessing the efficacy of seizure control and watching for any potential side effects. The decision should be individualized and ideally supported by drug level monitoring if available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decrease the dose: Decreasing the dose of retigabine would be counterproductive, as the enzyme-inducing effect of phenytoin would lower the drug levels, requiring an increase rather than a decrease.

 

Option C. Stop the drug: Stopping retigabine is not advisable without a clear indication of severe side effects or failure to control seizures. Retigabine can be an effective antiepileptic, and its discontinuation should be based on clinical judgment and not just due to the addition of another drug.

 

Option D. Stop retigabine and start on carbamazepine: This option suggests switching to another antiepileptic drug. While carbamazepine is another enzyme inducer like phenytoin, switching medications is not necessary unless there are specific reasons to do so, such as intolerability or ineffectiveness of retigabine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When phenytoin, an enzyme inducer, is added to a regimen that includes retigabine, the dose of retigabine should be increased to compensate for the increased metabolism and maintain effective seizure control.

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants causes the least sexual dysfunction? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mirtazapine

 

The typical antidepressants (SSRI, SNRI, MAO inhibitors and TCA) are notorious for causing sexual disturbances like erectile dysfunction due to increased levels of serotonin. On the other hand, atypical anti-depressants (like mirtazapine and bupropion etc) have lesser propensity to cause these adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Fluoxetine: As a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), fluoxetine is commonly associated with sexual dysfunction, including decreased libido, difficulty achieving orgasm, and erectile dysfunction.

 

Options B. Venlafaxine: This is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). While perhaps slightly less likely to cause sexual side effects than SSRIs, venlafaxine can still lead to sexual

dysfunction in a significant number of patients.

 

Options D. Imipramine: A tricyclic antidepressant (TCA), imipramine can cause sexual dysfunction, often due to its anticholinergic effects. TCAs, in general, are more likely to cause a variety of side effects, including those affecting sexual function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant. Apart from increasing the levels of serotonin and nor-adrenaline (due to blockade of presynaptic alpha 2 receptors), It also acts as an antagonist of serotonin (5-HT2 and 5-HT3) receptors. It has some degree of H1 blocking property also. It is therefore known as NSSA (Nor adrenergic and Specific Serotonergic Antidepressant). Mirtazapine is generally associated with a lower incidence of sexual side effects compared to SSRIs and SNRIs, making it a better option for patients concerned about these issues.

questions.text: What compound is responsible for the "coral-red" fluorescence observed under Wood's lamp examination in cases of Erythrasma? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coproporphyrin III

 

  • Erythrasma, caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum, shows a characteristic coral-red fluorescence under Wood's lamp examination due to the production of Coproporphyrin III by the bacteria. 

 

 

  • This fluorescence is a diagnostic feature of erythrasma and helps differentiate it from other similar-appearing conditions. 
  • When Wood's lamp (ultraviolet light at 365 nm wavelength) is shined on erythrasma lesions, the porphyrin compound emits this distinctive fluorescence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aminolevulonic acid (ALA) - This is incorrect. 

  • ALA is a precursor in the porphyrin synthesis pathway but is not directly responsible for the coral-red fluorescence in erythrasma. 
  • ALA is used in photodynamic therapy where it's metabolized to protoporphyrin IX, which fluoresces red under certain conditions.

 

Option C. Protoporphyrin IX - This is incorrect. 

  • Protoporphyrin IX is a porphyrin compound that can fluoresce red, but it's not the specific compound responsible for the coral-red fluorescence in erythrasma. 
  • Protoporphyrin IX accumulates in certain porphyrias and is used in photodynamic diagnosis.

 

Option D. Uroporphyrin I - This is incorrect. 

  • Uroporphyrin I is another porphyrin compound that can fluoresce, but it's not the specific compound that causes the coral-red fluorescence in erythrasma. 
  • Uroporphyrins accumulate in certain types of porphyria, particularly porphyria cutanea tarda.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coproporphyrin III produced by Corynebacterium minutissimum is responsible for the pathognomonic coral-red fluorescence observed under Wood's lamp examination in erythrasma, making this a valuable diagnostic test for this condition.

choices.text: Imprisonment for one year and/or a fine of Rs. 1000
Imprisonment for two years and/or a fine of Rs. 5000
Imprisonment for 1 month and/or a fine of Rs. 500

questions.text: A person "X" strikes another individual "Y" with a wooden stick after being provoked, resulting in a bruise measuring 3x3 cm on the forearm. No additional injuries are observed. Which of the following statements accurately reflects the potential punishment? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Imprisonment for 1 month and/or a fine of Rs. 500

 

Explanation:

 

The situation described involves a case of simple hurt. Person X has caused a 3×3 cm bruise on Y's forearm with a wooden stick after provocation, with no additional injuries. This constitutes a case of simple hurt under Section 323 IPC, which specifies imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five hundred rupees, or with both.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Imprisonment for one year and/or a fine of Rs. 1000 This punishment is excessive for simple hurt. This level of punishment would typically be associated with more serious offenses or aggravated forms of hurt.

 

Option B: Imprisonment for two years and/or a fine of Rs. 5000 This punishment is significantly excessive for simple hurt. This would be more appropriate for grievous hurt under Section 325 IPC, but the described injury (single bruise) does not qualify as grievous hurt.

 

Option D: Rigorous Imprisonment for six months the punishment is disproportionate to the offense described. Rigorous imprisonment for six months would be applicable for more serious offenses, not for causing a simple bruise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The above question is as per old laws. It is not applicable as per new laws.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in Static Two-point discrimination? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Merkel disk

 

Static two-point discrimination requires a receptor that adapts very slowly to maintain sensation over a prolonged period. Merkel cells are crucial for this function.

 

Merkel cells:

 

  • They are slow-adapting receptors
  • Excellent for 2-point discrimination
  • Have a less receptive field
  • Critical for detecting edges and points
  • Particularly important for tasks like Braille reading

 

The key characteristics that make Merkel cells ideal for static two-point discrimination are:

 

  1. Slow adaptation rate
  2. Ability to detect steady stimuli
  3. Precise localization of sensory input

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Meissner's corpuscles: Incorrect. These are rapidly adapting receptors, making them unsuitable for static discrimination. They are best for fine touch sensations.

 

Option C. Pacinian corpuscles: Incorrect. These are rapidly adapting receptors present at Deep dermis, joint capsule that sense high-frequency vibration and pressure, not static stimuli.

 

Option D. Ruffini ending: Incorrect. While these are slow-adapting mechanoreceptors, they primarily sense stretch and sustained pressure, not precise point discrimination.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: A - Cortisol B - Aldosterone C - Androgens D - Epinephrine
A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine
A - Epinephrine B - Cortisol C - Aldosterone D - Androgens
A - Aldosterone B - Epinephrine C - Androgens D - Cortisol

questions.text: Which hormones are produced from these zones? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine

 

Explanation:

 

The adrenal gland, located on top of the kidneys, consists of the adrenal cortex and the adrenal medulla. The cortex is further divided into three zones: the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis. These zones are responsible for producing different types of hormones, remembered by the mnemonic "GFR."

 

  • Zona Glomerulosa (A): This outermost layer is responsible for producing mineralocorticoids, the most important being Aldosterone. Aldosterone plays a critical role in regulating sodium and potassium balance in the body.
  • Zona Fasciculata (B): The middle layer produces glucocorticoids, primarily Cortisol. Cortisol is involved in stress response, metabolism regulation, and immune function.
  • Zona Reticularis (C): The innermost cortical layer produces androgens, specifically DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone), which is a precursor to sex steroids like testosterone and estrogen.
  • Adrenal Medulla (D): The medulla produces catecholamines, primarily Epinephrine (adrenaline), which is crucial for the fight-or-flight response.

 

Educational Objective:


The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones—zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis—which produce aldosterone, cortisol, and androgens, respectively. The adrenal medulla produces catecholamines, primarily epinephrine

questions.text: The motor supply of the muscle spindle is which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gamma neuron

 

Gamma motor neurons specifically innervate the intrafusal fibers within the muscle spindles, adjusting their tension and sensitivity to stretch, which is crucial for proper proprioceptive feedback.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha (α) neuron: Alpha motor neurons innervate extrafusal muscle fibers, which are the main contractile units of the muscle, and are not involved in the direct control of muscle spindle sensitivity.

 

Option C. Beta (β) neuron: A Beta neurons are sensory in nature, so they neither supply extrafusal nor intrafusal muscle fibers.

 

Option D. Delta (δ) neuron: Delta neurons are sensory neurons that transmit pain, temperature, and coarse touch sensations. They do not provide motor supply to muscle spindles or any other muscle fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma motor neurons (A gamma) specifically innervate the intrafusal fibers of muscle spindles, adjusting their tension and sensitivity to stretch, which is crucial for proper proprioceptive feedback.

questions.text: In a Pulmonary Function Test at what volume or capacity does the pressure measured at the upper airway reach zero?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Functional residual capacity

 

  • The functional residual capacity is the volume of the air that remains in the lungs after normal expiration. It is measured by a spirometer.
  • FRC → ERV + RV
  • At the lung volume corresponding to functional residual capacity (FRC), the lungs are in a relaxed state, and the pressure inside them becomes virtually negligible.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Residual volume: Incorrect. Residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation, but it does not correspond to the point where airway pressure is zero.

 

Option C. Total lung capacity: Incorrect. Total lung capacity is the maximum amount of air the lungs can hold, which includes all lung volumes, but it does not correspond to zero airway pressure.

 

Option D. Inspiratory capacity: Incorrect. Inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air that can be inhaled after a normal expiration, but it does not correspond to zero airway pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional residual capacity is the lung volume at which the pressure in the upper airway reaches zero, indicating a relaxed state of the lungs.

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

Plasma contains various components like ions, inorganic and organic molecules that help in the transport of substances across various parts of the body, such as Albumin, globulin, and fibrinogen fractions.

 

  1. Thyroxine is carried by transthyretin, also called thyroid-binding pre-albumin.
  2. Fatty acids are carried by albumin, which is a major carrier protein and osmotic regulator. It also transports hormones, amino acids, vitamins, and steroids.
  3. Hemoglobin binds to haptoglobin, which prevents free hemoglobin from being excreted in the urine.
  4. Heme binds with hemopexin for heme recycling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasma transporters like prealbumin, albumin, haptoglobin, and hemopexin play crucial roles in the transport and recycling of thyroxine, fatty acids, hemoglobin, and heme respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues are dependent on insulin for glucose uptake?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adipose tissue

 

Adipose tissue is dependent on insulin for glucose uptake.

 

Insulin stimulates glucose uptake into adipose tissue, promoting the storage of excess glucose as triglycerides in fat cells, thus regulating energy storage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain: The brain is capable of taking up glucose independent of insulin due to the presence of glucose transporter proteins that are insulin-independent, such as GLUT1. The brain has a high energy demand and relies heavily on glucose as its primary fuel source.

 

Option C. Pancreas: The pancreas does not take up significant amounts of glucose because its primary function is to produce and secrete insulin itself, among other hormones.

 

Option D. Kidney: The kidneys have glucose transporters, but they play a role in reabsorbing glucose from the urine back into the bloodstream rather than being dependent on insulin for glucose uptake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adipose tissue is dependent on insulin for glucose uptake, which facilitates the storage of glucose as triglycerides in fat cells.

questions.text: After reaching an equilibrium state during exercising, it was found that the body was consuming oxygen at the rate of 1500 ml/min. Calculate the MET score if the baseline oxygen consumption at rest is 250 ml/min? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6

 

MET (Metabolic Equivalent) is a unit used to estimate the energy expenditure of physical activities as a multiple of the resting metabolic rate (RMR). One MET is equal to the energy expended at rest, which is approximately 3.5 mL of oxygen per kilogram of body weight per minute (ml/kg/min).

 

To calculate the MET score for a given level of oxygen consumption, we need to first convert the oxygen consumption rate from ml/min to ml/kg/min, and then divide it by the resting oxygen consumption rate to get the MET value.

 

Assuming an average body weight of 70 kg, the oxygen consumption rate of 1500 ml/min corresponds to 21.4 ml/kg/min (1500 ml/min ÷ 70 kg).

 

Dividing this value by the resting oxygen consumption rate of 250 ml/min, we get:

 

MET score = 21.4 ml/kg/min ÷ 3.5 ml/kg/min ≈ 6

 

Therefore, the correct answer is B. 6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The MET score represents the energy expenditure of an activity as a multiple of the resting metabolic rate.

questions.text: The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the segment with the bolus of food during peristalsis is because of? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VIP

 

The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the segment with the bolus of food during peristalsis is due to the release of VIP (Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide) from the enteric nervous system.

 

VIP is a neuropeptide that is released by neurons in the myenteric plexus of the enteric nervous system. It causes relaxation of the smooth muscle in the intestinal wall, including the distal segment, through its action on VIP receptors located on the smooth muscle cells. This relaxation allows the bolus of food to move smoothly along the digestive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Substance P: Incorrect. Substance P is a neuropeptide involved in the regulation of gastrointestinal motility, primarily stimulating smooth muscle contraction rather than relaxation.

 

Option C. Dopamine from adrenergic fibres: Incorrect. Dopamine from adrenergic fibers is involved in the regulation of gastrointestinal motility, but it is not specifically responsible for the relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the bolus of food during peristalsis.

 

Option D. Acetylcholine from myenteric fibres: Incorrect. Acetylcholine from myenteric fibers is a neurotransmitter involved in the regulation of gastrointestinal motility, typically promoting contraction rather than relaxation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the bolus of food during peristalsis is mediated by the release of Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP) from the enteric nervous system, which causes smooth muscle relaxation and facilitates the smooth movement of the bolus through the digestive tract.

questions.text: Transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation is used to reduce pain. What is the mechanism behind this?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gate control theory

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief is based on the gate theory of pain.

 

According to gate control theory, the pain stimuli transmitted by afferent pain fibers are blocked by gate mechanism located at the posterior gray horn of spinal cord. If the gate is opened, pain is felt. If the gate is closed, pain is suppressed.

 

 

TENS activates a complex neuronal network using electrodes to result in a reduction in pain. At frequencies and intensities used clinically, TENS activates large diameter afferent fibers. This afferent input is sent to the central nervous system to activate descending inhibitory systems to reduce hyperalgesia. Specifically, blockade of neuronal activity in the periaqueductal gray (PAG), rostral ventromedial medulla (RVM) and spinal cord inhibit the analgesic effects of TENS showing that TENS analgesia is maintained through these pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central inhibition: Incorrect. Central inhibition is not the primary mechanism of action for TENS in pain relief.

 

Option B. Desensitization: Incorrect. Desensitization refers to a reduction in response to a stimulus over time, which is not the primary mechanism for TENS.

 

Option D. Descending inhibition: Incorrect. While descending inhibitory pathways are involved in the modulation of pain, the gate control theory specifically explains the mechanism behind TENS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) reduces pain through the gate control theory, which involves blocking pain signals at the spinal cord level by activating large diameter afferent fibers.

questions.text: After parotidectomy, lower lip paralysis was seen in a patient. Which of the following part of facial nerve was involved ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

 

The cervical branch of the facial nerve is responsible for innervating the platysma muscle, which is crucial for controlling lower lip movements. During a parotidectomy, if this branch is damaged, it can lead to paralysis of the lower lip.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parotid duct: The parotid duct is not a part of the facial nerve. It is a salivary duct and does not contribute to nerve innervation.

 

Option B. Temporal branch of facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates the muscles of the forehead, including the frontalis, corrugator supercilii, and orbicularis oculi. It does not affect lower lip movements.

 

Option D. Main trunk of facial nerve: The main trunk of the facial nerve divides into several branches, including the temporal and cervical branches. It is not directly responsible for the lower lip movement, as it provides the general innervation before splitting into specific branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the cervical branch of the facial nerve during a parotidectomy can result in lower lip paralysis.

choices.text: The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.
The left adrenal gland is closely related with the tail of pancreas and spleen.
The adrenal are yellow on gross appearance.
The adrenal are retroperitoneal in location.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the anatomy of the adrenal glands?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.

 

 

  • The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape: This statement is false. The right adrenal gland is actually pyramidal in shape. The left adrenal gland is semi-lunar (crescent-shaped) in shape. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The left adrenal gland is closely related with the tail of pancreas and spleen: This statement is true. The left adrenal gland is anatomically positioned near the tail of the pancreas and the spleen.

 

Option C. The adrenal are yellow on gross appearance: This statement is true. The adrenal glands have a yellowish appearance on gross examination due to their rich lipid content.

 

Option D. The adrenal are retroperitoneal in location: This statement is true. The adrenal glands, like the kidneys, are retroperitoneal, meaning they are located behind the peritoneum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The right adrenal gland is pyramidal in shape, while the left adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.

questions.text: All of the following cranial nerve nuclei are part of special visceral afferent column except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trochlear nerve

 

The trochlear nerve nucleus belongs to the general somatic efferent column (GSE), not the special visceral afferent column. Special visceral afferent refers to sensory information associated with taste and smell.

 

The trochlear nerve is a motor nerve that innervates the orbit's superior oblique muscle.

 

The neurons of the general somatic efferent (GSE) column innervate the extrinsic ocular and tongue muscles (III, IV, VI, and XII cranial nerves).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial Nerve (CN VII):

 

  • Sensory Component: The facial nerve carries special visceral afferent fibers responsible for taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue (via the chorda tympani branch).
  • Motor Component: The facial nerve also contains motor fibers responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression.

 

Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X):

 

  • Sensory Component: The vagus nerve carries special visceral afferent fibers responsible for taste sensation from the epiglottis and the root of the tongue.
  • Motor Component: The vagus nerve has a wide range of motor functions, including control of the muscles involved in swallowing and vocalization, as well as autonomic functions.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal Nerve (CN IX):

 

  • Sensory Component: The glossopharyngeal nerve carries special visceral afferent fibers responsible for taste sensation from the posterior one-third of the tongue and sensory input from the oropharynx.
  • Motor Component: It also has motor functions, including control of certain muscles involved in swallowing.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Physiological hernia failing to go back

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the embryological basis for the formation of an omphalocele? ( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Physiological hernia failing to go back

 

  • Omphalocele is characterized by the herniation of abdominal viscera through an enlarged umbilical ring.
  • Amnion protects the viscera, which may include the liver, small and large intestines, stomach, spleen, or gallbladder.
  • The defect is caused by the bowel's failure to return to the body cavity after its physiological herniation between the sixth and tenth weeks.

 

 

Omphalocele is associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive length of the intestine: During early embryonic development, the intestines do grow at a rapid pace, leading to temporary herniation of the midgut into the umbilical cord around the 6th week. This is called physiological midgut herniation. The intestines then rotate and usually return into the abdominal cavity by the 10th week. It's not the excessive length of the intestine itself that causes omphalocele; rather, it's the failure of the intestines (and sometimes other organs) to return to the abdominal cavity.

 

Option C. Herniation of liver: While the liver can indeed be one of the organs present in an omphalocele, its herniation is not the primary cause of omphalocele. Instead, it is a consequence of the failure of the physiological hernia to return to the abdominal cavity. In larger omphaloceles, the liver is more commonly seen as part of the herniated content.

 

Option D. Herniation of umbilicus: This option is not precise. The umbilicus itself is not what herniates in omphalocele. Instead, it's through the region of the umbilicus that the intestines and possibly other organs herniate out into the umbilical cord during development. If they fail to return to the abdomen, an omphalocele forms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalocele is primarily caused by the failure of the physiological hernia of the midgut to return to the abdominal cavity during fetal development, not merely by the excessive length of the intestine or specific organ herniation.

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical landmarks is not commonly used for identifying the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior belly of omohyoid muscle

 

The omohyoid muscle is a thin, flat muscle in the anterior neck, and it has no direct anatomical relation to the facial nerve trunk. Therefore, it is not used as a landmark to identify the facial nerve trunk during surgeries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrograde dissection from distal branch: This involves tracing the facial nerve branches from their more distal and superficial positions back towards their origin at the main trunk of the facial nerve. This is a common technique used by surgeons, especially when there is difficulty locating the main trunk due to factors like inflammation, previous surgery, or anatomical variations.

 

Option B. Tragal pointer: It is a small cartilaginous projection at the anterior margin of the external auditory meatus, from the tragus of the ear. The main trunk of the facial nerve typically lies about 1 cm deep and slightly inferior to the tragal pointer, making it a reliable landmark to locate the facial nerve trunk during parotid gland surgeries.

 

Option D. Posterior belly of digastric: The posterior belly of the digastric muscle is another important anatomical landmark in parotid surgeries. The main trunk of the facial nerve is usually found superficial and medial to the posterior belly of the digastric muscle. This muscle serves as a consistent landmark to help in locating the facial nerve trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods to identify the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgeries:

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Circumvallate

 

  • The given histological image is a section of the tongue displaying circumvallate papillae, which are the largest papillae present on the tongue.
  • They are cylindrical in shape, and usually around 8-12 in no.
  • They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and are arranged in a V-shaped row immediately in front of the sulcus terminalis on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
  • They are narrower at their base than their apex and contain numerous taste buds (around 250 for each papilla) within their walls. These taste buds contain chemosensory cells that synapse with the gustatory nerves, enabling the sense of taste.
  • In addition, the serous glands of von Ebner empty via ducts into the base of the sulcus, which helps to flush out food particles from the area surrounding the papillae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Fungiform papillae are protrusions on the tongue that are relatively large, round, and reddish in color. They can be found on both the dorsal surface and the lingual margins of the tongue, and are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

 

Option C: Filiform papillae are small, conical or cylindrical projections located mainly on the dorsal surface of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. They lack taste buds and are covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. All other papillae, except filiform, contain taste buds.

 

Option D: Foliate papillae are red, leaf-like mucosal ridges located bilaterally in two zones at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis. They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Circumvallate papilla are located on the dorsum of the tongue, forming a V-shaped row in front of the terminal sulcus (the V-shaped groove that separates the anterior two-thirds from the posterior third of the tongue). They are the largest papillae, about 8-12 in number, and have a round, raised shape. Each is surrounded by a trench (or moat), hence the name 'circumvallate.

questions.text: Examine the histological section provided. Which type of cartilage is shown in the image?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. White fibrocartilage

 

The given image shows prominent collagen fibers arranged in bundles with intervening rows of chondrocytes. This is suggestive of white fibrocartilage.

 

Microscopy of fibrocartilage shows the following:

 

  • Chondrocytes- Round in shape (in tendons they are flattened and elongated)
  • Ground tissue with collagen fibers- Type I collagen fibers
  • Absence of perichondrium

 

Note - White fibrocartilage is dense with collagen fibers (primarily type I collagen), which gives a great tensile strength. It is found in intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis, menisci of the knee, and places where tendons insert into bones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-articular hyaline cartilage: It's a type of hyaline cartilage not involved in joint articulations. The matrix contains a moderate amount of collagen fibers, predominantly type II collagen, making it tough but somewhat flexible. It is found in the respiratory tract (including the trachea, bronchi, and nasal cartilages), growth plates of bones, and the anterior aspect of ribs (costal cartilages).

 

Option B. Articular hyaline cartilage: It is similar in composition to non-articular hyaline cartilage, but specifically lines the surfaces of bones in synovial joints. It covers the ends of bones in synovial joints such as the knee, shoulder, and hip.

 

Option C. Yellow cartilage (Elastic cartilage): It contains elastic fibers and collagen fibers, mainly type II collagen. The elastic fibers give it more flexibility than hyaline cartilage. It is found in the ear pinna (auricle), epiglottis, and auditory (Eustachian) tubes.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A woman, who is 5 days postpartum, presented with tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Postpartum blues

 

Postpartum blues, or "baby blues," typically present within a 3-5 days post-delivery with mood swings, tearfulness, and mild insomnia. These symptoms resolve within a week or two.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postpartum depression: Is more severe and persistent, lasting beyond 2 weeks, often requiring intervention.

 

Option C. Postpartum psychosis: Is a rare, severe condition manifesting with hallucinations, delusions, and potential risk to the infant.

 

Option D. Postpartum anxiety: Involves excessive worry about the baby's well-being, often without the characteristic mood swings of the blues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

 

Reference: Textbook of Women’s Reproductive Mental Health, Page No 352

questions.text: A medical student presented with complaints of repeated episodes lasting approximately 30 minutes, characterized by breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and a fear of an impending heart attack. The patient has experienced these episodes 5-6 times per month over the last 6 months, and investigations did not reveal any obvious abnormalities. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Panic Disorder

 

The clinical presentation of a medical student with repeated episodes of breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and fear of an impending heart attack, each lasting approximately 30 minutes and occurring 5-6 times per month over the last 6 months, with no abnormalities found in investigations, is highly suggestive of Panic Disorder. Panic Disorder is characterized by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks, which are abrupt surges of intense fear or discomfort reaching a peak within minutes. The symptoms described, including palpitations, sweating, and hyperventilation, are common during panic attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD): GAD is characterized by persistent and excessive worry about various things, but it does not typically involve the acute, intense episodes of fear or the physical symptoms of a panic attack.

 

Option C. Depression: While depression can have anxiety symptoms and panic attacks, the primary feature is a persistent low mood and loss of interest or pleasure in activities, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option D. Social Phobia: Also known as social anxiety disorder, this involves a significant fear of social or performance situations. The symptoms described do not specifically relate to social or performance situations, making this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with anticipatory anxiety. Patients may start ‘avoiding’ situations that they link with the panic attack. Treatment includes a combination of pharmacotherapy [benzodiazepines for short term and SSRIs for long term] and psychotherapy [CBT, relaxation techniques] is preferred.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 402.

questions.text: Which of the following drug used in ADHD is a Selective Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitor? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reboxetine

  

Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) primarily used as an antidepressant. It selectively inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine, enhancing its concentration in the synaptic cleft, which is beneficial in treating ADHD symptoms. Although it is not commonly used as a first-line treatment for ADHD, it can be prescribed off-label in certain cases due to its mechanism of action targeting norepinephrine, which plays a significant role in attention and impulse control.

 

Note – Atomoxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), used in treating ADHD, but not mentioned in option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Modafinil: Modafinil is a stimulant that promotes wakefulness and is used primarily for conditions like narcolepsy and sleep disorders. It is not a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and works mainly by influencing dopamine pathways, making it unsuitable as an answer.

 

Option C. Methylphenidate: Methylphenidate is a central nervous system stimulant commonly used to treat ADHD, but it works primarily by inhibiting the reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine rather than selectively targeting norepinephrine alone.

 

Option D. Guanfacine: Guanfacine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used in the treatment of ADHD. It does not inhibit norepinephrine reuptake but instead works by stimulating alpha-2 receptors, which reduces sympathetic nerve impulses, leading to a calming effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) that can be used off-label for ADHD, distinct from other ADHD medications that target both norepinephrine and dopamine or act on other neurotransmitter systems.

choices.text: Head neck, thoracic and abdominal triage

questions.text: What are the different levels of triage in emergency care? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate, delayed, and minimal triage

 

The different levels of triage in emergency care are immediate, delayed, and minimal triage.

 

Immediate triage (red tag) is the highest priority and is given to patients who have life-threatening injuries or illnesses that require prompt medical attention. Examples of immediate triage include patients with severe bleeding or difficulty breathing.

 

Delayed triage (yellow tag) is given to patients who have injuries or illnesses that are not immediately life-threatening but require medical attention. Examples of delayed triage include patients with open fractures or moderate burns.

 

Minimal triage (green tag) is given to patients who have minor injuries or illnesses that do not require immediate medical attention. Examples of minimal triage include patients with minor cuts or bruises.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage helps to ensure that patients receive the appropriate level of care based on their condition and the resources available. By prioritizing patients based on the severity of their injuries or illnesses, emergency medical personnel can provide the best possible care to the greatest number of patients in a disaster or emergency situation.

questions.text: What would be the next suitable examination for a chronic smoker, aged 40, who is experiencing blue discoloration of the toe and intermittent claudication? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Duplex scan

 

The duplex scan is a type of ultrasound that combines traditional ultrasound with Doppler ultrasound. It can visualize the structure of blood vessels and the flow of blood within them. It is non-invasive, doesn't require the use of contrast media, and can provide immediate results. Given the patient's symptoms of blue discoloration of the toe (suggesting compromised blood flow) and intermittent claudication (pain in the legs while walking, indicating peripheral artery disease), a duplex scan is an excellent first choice to evaluate the patency of the arteries and the location and severity of any blockages. For a chronic smoker with these symptoms, a duplex scan is a commonly used initial diagnostic tool to evaluate peripheral arterial disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT Angiography: Computed tomography angiography (CTA) is a diagnostic tool that combines X-ray technology with computer imaging to visualize blood flow in the arteries. While it can provide detailed images of blood vessels and can identify blockages or other vascular problems, it requires the injection of a contrast medium, exposes the patient to radiation, and might not be the first-line diagnostic tool in this scenario.

 

Option B. MR Angiography: Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is a type of MRI that looks specifically at blood vessels. It provides detailed images of arteries and can be useful in detecting vascular problems. However, it might not be the first choice for initial evaluation, especially when quicker, less expensive, and equally informative tests are available, like the duplex scan.

 

Option C. Digital subtraction angiography: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is an invasive procedure that involves injecting a contrast medium into the blood vessels and taking X-ray images. It provides detailed visualization of the inner structures of blood vessels and is particularly useful for planning interventions. However, due to its invasive nature, it is typically done if planning a vascular intervention like balloon dilation or stenting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Chronic smoking can cause peripheral arterial disease, which can present with bluish discoloration of the toe and intermittent claudication.
  • Duplex Scanning is a non-invasive technique that uses ultrasound to provide an image of the vessel and can be used to investigate this condition.
  • Duplex Scanning allows for detailed visualization of blood flow within the vessel, with different colors indicating changes in direction and velocity of flow.

questions.text: An inguinal hernia with acute appendicitis occurring in the sac is known as: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Amyand’s Hernia

 

Explanation:

 

Amyand's hernia is specifically defined as an inguinal hernia where the content is the appendix. When the appendix becomes inflamed within the hernia sac, it represents a case of acute appendicitis occurring within an Amyand's hernia.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Richter's Hernia: This occurs when only part of the bowel wall circumference is the content of the hernia. It typically doesn't present with intestinal obstruction but can directly progress to strangulation.
  • Option B. Littre's Hernia: This is defined as a hernia where the content is Meckel's diverticulum, not the appendix.
  • Option D. Maydl's Hernia: This refers to a double loop of intestine within the hernia sac.

 

Named Hernias at a glance:

  1. Omentocele - Content is omentum
  2. Enterocele - Content is intestine
  3. Richter's - Part of bowel wall circumference is in the sac
  4. Littre's - Content is Meckel's diverticulum
  5. Maydl's - Double loop of intestine
  6. Amyand's - Content is appendix
  7. Sliding hernia - Organs like cecum (right) or sigmoid (left) accompany the sac and form a part of the wall of the sac

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Amyand's hernia is specifically an inguinal hernia containing the appendix, regardless of whether the appendix is inflamed or normal.

choices.text: Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories
A child of 16 years can be employed only between 6 AM and 8 PM
The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week
A child of 16 years can work till 5 hours per day

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Factories Act? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories 

 

  • The Factories Act, established in 1948, specifically prohibits the employment of children under 14 years of age in factories. 
  • This legislation was enacted to ensure the protection of children from labor exploitation and to promote their welfare by restricting their employment in industrial environments.

 

FACTORIES ACT:

 

  • Established to include all the factories except Defense, Mining, Railways and Eateries.
  • Per capita space: more than 500/ft3
  • One Safety officer for more than 1000 workers.
  • Children between 14-18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM-7PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.
  • The maximum working hours for adults should be less than 48hrs per week or less than 9hrs per day.
  • With overtime being included, it should not be more than 60 hours per week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Factories Act of 1948 critically mandates that children under the age of 14 must not be employed in factories, reflecting the law's strong stance on child labor and its emphasis on the health and safety of young individuals.

choices.text: It can be reduced by matching
It is associated individually with both cause and effect
It is distributed equally in both study and control groups
It is associated with the exposure of the study

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding a confounding factor? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) It is distributed equally in both study and control groups

 

  • Confounding factor: Any factor associated with both exposure and outcome, and has an independent effect in causation of outcome is a confounder.
  • It is found unequally distributed between the study and control groups

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It can be reduced by matching:  Matching is a technique used in study design to control for confounding by ensuring that study groups are comparable with respect to potential confounders.

 

Option C. It is distributed equally in both study and control groups:  This statement is incorrect. A confounding factor is typically unequally distributed between the study and control groups. If it were equally distributed, it would not confound the results.

 

Option D. It is associated with the exposure of the study:  A confounder is associated with the exposure and can influence the observed effect of the exposure on the outcome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Confounding can be removed by

 

1. Matching → MC used /simplest method

2. Randomization → 2nd Best Method

3. Restriction

4. Stratification

5. Statistical Modelling / Multivariate analysis (MVA)

6. Stratified Randomization → Overall Best Method

choices.text: Cervical Pap smear in a 40-year-old patient
Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism
Screening of immigrants to a country
Urine for sugar screening in a 40-year-old man

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Screening of immigrants to a country

 

Prospective screening is conducted primarily for the benefit of the community or the public health system, rather than for the direct benefit of the individual being screened. It aims to control the spread of diseases and protect public health by identifying potential carriers of infectious diseases or individuals with certain health conditions that may pose a risk to others.

 

Screening of immigrants to a country: This is a classic example of prospective screening. It is done to detect infectious diseases or other health conditions in immigrants to prevent the spread of disease and protect the health of the population in the host country. This screening is often mandated by public health authorities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical Pap smear in a 40-year-old patient:  This is an example of prescriptive screening, as it is conducted for the individual's benefit to detect cervical cancer early.

 

Option B. Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism:  This is also an example of prescriptive screening aimed at early detection and management of hypothyroidism in newborns.

 

Option D. Urine for sugar screening in a 40-year-old man:  This is another example of prescriptive screening, used to detect diabetes in the individual.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The floods had an impact on Kerala's Pathanamthitta district, leading the government to provide doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis. What other chemical is set to be distributed in conjunction with this? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Zinc phosphide

 

Explanation - 

 

The government distributed doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis following floods in Kerala to prevent the spread of diseases such as leptospirosis, acute diarrheal diseases, and dengue.

  • Leptospirosis, which is caused by contaminated water with rodent urine, can be prevented by chemoprophylaxis with Doxycycline, using rubber shoes and gloves, anti-rodent measures, and establishing a proper drainage system.
  • Zinc phosphide is used for chemical control of rodents due to its good safety record, low cost and high effectiveness
  • Chlorine tablets and bleaching powder are used to disinfect household water supply. Insecticides and larvicides like abate are used for indoor residual sprays for drinking water.
  • General hygiene and sanitary measures must also be followed to control the spread of diseases during floods.

choices.text: Testing all the dogs for rabies
Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs
Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance

questions.text: While numerous animals play a role in the transmission of rabies, dogs stand out as the most common ones. Moreover, the impact of this disease is often more in children. Given this understanding, what approach would be both economically efficient and rational to reduce the occurrence of rabies? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs

 

Since dogs are the primary source of infection, the most cost-effective (and logical) strategy would be Elimination of stray dogs and taking a step towards mass immunization. This approach directly addresses the primary source of infection and helps break the transmission cycle of the rabies virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testing all the dogs for rabies: Not economically efficient due to the large number of dogs and the high cost of testing. It also does not prevent the spread of the disease.

 

Option C. Strengthening laboratory facilities: While important for diagnosis and monitoring, this does not address the primary prevention of rabies through vaccination and control of the dog population.

 

Option D. Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance: Surveillance is crucial but does not directly prevent rabies transmission. It is more of a reactive approach rather than a proactive prevention strategy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reducing the stray dog population and vaccinating all dogs is the most economically efficient and rational approach to reduce the occurrence of rabies. This strategy directly targets the primary source of infection and helps prevent the spread of the disease.

questions.text: Research is being conducted to find the association between aniline dye exposure and bladder cancer in workers who have worked in the industry for >20 years. Two groups were formed: one directly involved with dye handling and the other group consisting of office clerks not directly exposed to the dye. Years of occupation were noted from records. Then Bladder cancer cases were identified from both the groups in the current time. What type of study is being performed? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Retrospective cohort study

 

The study given here is a retrospective cohort study.

 

A retrospective cohort study is when both the exposure and outcome have occurred before commencing the investigations and study.

 

The given question tells that the workers in the industry were divided into two groups, first are those who are directly exposed and second are clerical staff who are not directly exposed to the suspected carcinogen.

 

The incidence of bladder cancer among these two groups is studied going backward tracking their records. Therefore, it’s a retrospective cohort study.

 

A simple comparison between these studies and an example is shown below:
 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prospective cohort study: Involves following a group over a time span till the development of outcome.

 

Option C. Case-control study: A case-control study involves comparing groups with a specific outcome (cases) with a rather healthy group (controls) and assessing their exposure history. In this case, workers are divided into groups based on their exposure status and the development of bladder cancer.

 

Option D. Intervention and response: Is not a type of epidemiological study design.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A retrospective cohort study involves examining historical data to investigate the relationship between exposure and outcomes. In this scenario, it is used to study the association between aniline dye exposure and bladder cancer among workers over a 20-year period.

questions.text: Full form of JSSK is? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram


JSSK stands for Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram. It was introduced as an extension of the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), which was launched in 2005 under the National Rural Health Mission. The older name of JSY was National Maternity Benefit Scheme.

 

Initially, JSY focused only on maternal health, emphasizing the safety and wellbeing of the mother (Janani). However, recognizing the interconnected nature of maternal and newborn health, the program was expanded to include newborn care (Shishu), leading to the creation of JSSK on June 1, 2011 under NRHM. JSSK aims to provide free and cashless services to pregnant women and sick newborns, including transport, medicines, and diet, focusing on enhancing the overall health of both mother and child (upto 1 year of age).

 

Educational Objective:
 

JSSK stands for Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram, focusing on the protection and care of both the mother and infant by providing comprehensive healthcare services

choices.text: The rule is associated with bullet injuries to the cranium
It is utilized to ascertain the sequence of bullet shots
This rule involves the observation of fracture lines
It is valuable in cases where multiple bullet injuries occur simultaneously

questions.text: Regarding Puppe's rule, all of the following statements are true EXCEPT: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. It is valuable in cases where multiple bullet injuries occur simultaneously.

 

Explanation: 

 

Puppe's rule states that when two fracture lines intersect each other, the second fracture line never crosses the first one. This principle is crucial for determining the sequence of impacts in cases of multiple skull fractures. The rule specifically helps in establishing chronology - which impact occurred first and which occurred subsequently. For this rule to be applicable, the fractures must have occurred at different times, not simultaneously. This makes option D incorrect because Puppe's rule has no value in cases where multiple bullet injuries occur simultaneously, as the rule is specifically designed to determine sequence over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The rule is associated with bullet injuries to the cranium - This is true. Puppe's rule is applied in cases of cranial fractures, including those caused by bullet injuries, to determine the sequence of impacts.

 

Option B. It is utilized to ascertain the sequence of bullet shots - This is true. The primary purpose of Puppe's rule is to determine the sequence of impacts when multiple fractures are present.

 

Option C. This rule involves the observation of fracture lines - This is true. Puppe's rule is based on observing how fracture lines intersect each other. The second fracture line stops at or is deflected by the first fracture line.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Puppe's rule is a forensic principle that helps determine the sequence of multiple impacts to the skull by analyzing how fracture lines intersect, but it has no value in cases where injuries occur simultaneously.

questions.text: The antiviral drug having dual antiviral activity against HIV and HBV is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Emtricitabine

 

Emtricitabine is a NRTI that has dual action against both HIV and Hepatitis B. The drugs having activity against both HIV and HBV are:

 

L: Lamivudine

 

E: Emtricitabine


T: Tenofovir
 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enfuvirtide: Enfuvirtide is an entry inhibitor used exclusively for HIV. It works by preventing the HIV virus from entering human immune cells but does not have activity against HBV.

 

Option B. Abacavir: Abacavir is an NRTI used for HIV treatment. While it is effective against HIV, it does not have activity against HBV.

 

Option D. Ritonavir: Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV. It is primarily used to boost the levels of other protease inhibitors through its inhibition of the cytochrome P450 3A4 enzyme. Ritonavir does not have activity against HBV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emtricitabine is an antiviral drug with dual activity against both HIV and HBV, making it a valuable component in the treatment of patients co-infected with these viruses. Other drugs with dual activity include lamivudine and tenofovir.

questions.text: Apparent volume of distribution of a drug is very high (6L/kg). Which of the following is true regarding the distribution of that drug? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sequestered in body tissues

 

  • A Vd (volume of distribution) of 6 L/kg means approx. 420 L (6 x 70) in a 70 Kg person. It is much higher than blood volume of 5L.
  • A high Vd suggests that the drug is extensively distributed beyond the blood and into the tissues. This often implies that the drug has a high affinity for tissues, effectively getting "sequestered" or stored there.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Highly bound to plasma proteins: A drug that is highly bound to plasma proteins would typically have a lower Vd because it is mostly confined to the bloodstream. Plasma protein binding keeps the drug within the vascular space, preventing its distribution into tissues.

 

Option B. Confined to vascular compartment: A low Vd would suggest that the drug is primarily in the vascular compartment, including plasma and blood cells. A high Vd of 6L/kg indicates the opposite, suggesting that the drug is widely distributed in tissues rather than confined to the vascular compartment.

 

Therefore, a high Vd suggests that the drug is stored or sequestered in various body tissues, making option C the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A high volume of distribution (Vd) suggests that the drug is widely distributed throughout the body and sequestered in various tissues, rather than being confined to the bloodstream or vascular compartment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has experienced the loss of her newborn. She is currently producing breast milk, leading to discomfort and the risk of developing a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. Which of the following drug can be used to prevent this complication? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cabergoline

 

In this scenario, the goal is to prevent lactation to avoid discomfort and the risk of developing a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. The appropriate treatment involves using a drug that can suppress prolactin secretion, as prolactin is the hormone responsible for stimulating milk production.

 

Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist that inhibits prolactin secretion, effectively suppressing lactation. It is often used for this purpose and can be an effective choice in this situation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: Mifepristone is an antiprogestin used for medical termination of pregnancy. It does not have a direct role in suppressing lactation.

 

Option C. Chlorpromazine: Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic medication that can increase prolactin levels, which would not be helpful in this context.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent and antiemetic that also increases prolactin levels, making it unsuitable for suppressing lactation.

 

Given these options, the correct choice for preventing lactation and thus avoiding the associated complications is: b. Cabergoline

questions.text: A pregnant woman was prescribed indomethacin. Which of the following effects does the drug have on the fetus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Premature closure of ductus arteriosus

 

Indomethacin is an NSAID, that acts by inhibiting the Cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme, thereby decreasing the synthesis of Prostaglandins. Prostaglandins are necessary for maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus in the fetus. Therefore, Indomethacin if given to a pregnant woman can lead to premature closure of the ductus arteriosus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Keeps ductus arteriosus patent: Indomethacin does not keep the ductus arteriosus patent; instead, it promotes its closure by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.

 

Option C. Closure of fossa ovalis: The closure of the fossa ovalis is not influenced by indomethacin. The fossa ovalis is a different fetal structure that closes postnatally due to changes in pressure gradients.

 

Option D. Premature closure of ductus venous: The ductus venosus closure is not affected by indomethacin. This structure typically closes naturally after birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indomethacin, an NSAID, can cause the premature closure of the ductus arteriosus in a fetus due to its inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis. Therefore, caution should be exercised when prescribing this drug to pregnant women, particularly in the third trimester.

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was started on a new drug. After 2 days, he presented with the given finding. Which of the following drugs is implicated in causing the below condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Warfarin

 

The figure shows clinical picture of dermal vascular necrosis, also known as ‘purple toe syndrome’. It is an early adverse effect of warfarin. It is seen in patients with genetic protein C deficiency.

 

Dermal Vascular Necrosis

 

  • Warfarin-induced dermal vascular necrosis is a rare complication of warfarin therapy.
  • It characterized by the development of painful skin lesions in patients taking warfarin.
  • It is thought to be caused by a transient hypercoagulable state resulting from a rapid reduction in protein C levels in patients with underlying protein C deficiency or other risk factors.
  • The lesions typically occur in areas with a high concentration of adipose tissue, such as the breasts, thighs, and buttocks.
  • The initial symptoms include red or purple spots on the skin that can quickly progress to painful, necrotic lesions with a central blister or eschar.
  • The diagnosis is usually made clinically based on the characteristic appearance of the lesions and the patient's history of warfarin therapy.
  • The treatment of dermal vascular necrosis involves stopping warfarin and initiating alternative anticoagulant therapy, such as heparin or low molecular weight heparin.
  • In severe cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to remove the necrotic tissue and prevent further damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that works by activating antithrombin III, which in turn inhibits thrombin and factor Xa. It does not cause dermal vascular necrosis. However, heparin can cause other complications such as heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

 

Option C. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor used as an anticoagulant. It does not cause dermal vascular necrosis and is generally associated with a different profile of side effects, including bleeding.

 

Option D. Rivaroxaban: Rivaroxaban is a direct factor Xa inhibitor used for anticoagulation. It does not cause dermal vascular necrosis and is associated with a different side effect profile, mainly related to bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin can cause dermal vascular necrosis, particularly in patients with protein C deficiency, presenting as painful, necrotic skin lesions shortly after initiation of therapy.

questions.text: Name the drug that acts on both the marked points: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Omapatrilat

 

Omapatrilat is a inhibits both neprilysin and Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE). As a result, there is a decrease in Angiotensin II and increase in natriuretic peptide levels, promoting natriuresis, diuresis, vasodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sacubitril: Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin reducing breakdown of vasoactive peptides such as natriuretic peptides and bradykinin, therefore increasing their levels leading to vasodilation, diuresis, and counteracting the effects of RAAS. Sacubitril is combined with an ARB, valsartan is indicated for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

 

Option C. Losartan: Losartan is classified under angiotensin receptor blocker, used in the treatment of hypertension. A/E are Hyperkalemia, Dysgeusia, Postural hypotension. C/I in pregnancy, B/L Renal Artery Stenosis. Losartan decreases serum uric acid levels.

 

Option D. Nesiritide: Nesiritide is a synthetic brain natriuretic peptide (BNP), acts as a natriuretic and vasodilator. Primarily used in acute decompensated heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omapatrilat inhibits both neprilysin and angiotensin-converting enzyme, thereby decreasing angiotensin II and increasing natriuretic peptides, promoting natriuresis, diuresis, and vasodilation.

choices.text: Impairment of consciousness
Being unaware of one's problems
Difficulty in identifying known faces
Failure to identify objects

questions.text: What is Prosopagnosia?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Difficulty in identifying known faces

 

Explanation

 

Prosopagnosia (also known as face blindness or facial agnosia) is a neurological disorder characterized by the inability to recognize faces. An autonomic response may be produced in response to a familiar face.

 

Note - Prosopagnosia is not related to memory dysfunction, memory loss, impaired vision, or learning disabilities. The disorder is thought to be the result of congenital influence, damage, or impairment in a fold in the brain that appears to coordinate the neural systems controlling facial perception and memory (right fusiform gyrus). 

 

Face recognitions is represented mainly in the right inferior temporal lobe, but left lobe is also involved and injury to this area cause prosopagnosia. Prosopagnosia can result from stroke, traumatic brain injury (TBI), or certain neurodegenerative diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Impairment of consciousness: Incorrect because prosopagnosia specifically relates to difficulty in recognizing faces, not general impairments of consciousness.

 

Option B. Being unaware of one's problems: Incorrect as this describes anosognosia, not prosopagnosia.

 

Option D. Failure to identify objects: Incorrect because this defines object agnosia, whereas prosopagnosia is specifically the inability to recognize faces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize faces, often due to damage to the right fusiform gyrus and related brain areas involved in facial perception and memory, distinct from general memory loss or vision impairment.

 

Note:

 

  • Autotopagnosia - inability to recognize or to orient different parts of one's own body
  • Simultagnosia -the inability to perceive more than one object at a time.
  • Somatagnosia - inability to identify any part of the body, either one's own or another's body
  • Tactile agnosia (stereognosia) - inability to recognize objects by touch

choices.text: It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia
Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs
Rigidity is pronounced
It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs

questions.text: Which of the following is true for decorticate rigidity? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs

 

Explanation

 

Decorticate animal is the one without cerebral cortex.

 

In man, decorticate condition is caused by intracranial hemorrhage, head injury, brain abscess or brain tumor. Decorticate condition is called decorticate rigidity

 

Decorticate rigidity is the abnormal postural changes that involve rigid extension of the lower limbs and flexion of the upper limbs at elbow joint across the chest. Wrists and fingers are also flexed. Posture may develop on one side or both sides of the body.

 

Reflexes at the neck level can be elicited

 

  • When the neck is turned to right, there is flexion of the lower and upper limbs on the opposite side. But, on the same side, there is extension of the limbs.
  • It may be due to the cutting or lesion of direct corticospinal tract. Some fibers of corticospinal tract are known to have inhibitory influence on the extensor muscles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia: Incorrect as decorticate rigidity typically does not involve the removal of the basal ganglia.

 

Option B. Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs: Incorrect as this describes a reverse of the decorticate rigidity posturing.

 

Option C. Rigidity is pronounced: This statement is somewhat vague but could be considered true in the context of how muscle rigidity is indeed pronounced in decorticate rigidity. However, it does not specifically describe the characteristic posture associated with decorticate rigidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decorticate rigidity is characterized by flexion of the upper limbs and extension of the lower limbs, often occurring in response to severe brain damage above the midbrain level. It is a distinctive postural manifestation of significant central nervous system disruption.

choices.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
 

Explanation

 

'C' wave in JVP represents tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contraction of right atrium: This is incorrect for the 'C' wave. The contraction of the right atrium produces the 'A' wave in the JVP, not the 'C' wave. The 'A' wave occurs due to atrial contraction pushing blood against a closed tricuspid valve at the end of diastole.

 

Option C. Passive filling of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive filling of the right atrium contributes to the 'V' wave, which occurs when the right atrium fills with blood during ventricular systole and the tricuspid valve is closed.

 

Option D. Passive emptying of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive emptying of the right atrium is associated with the 'Y' descent, which happens when the tricuspid valve opens in early diastole and blood flows from the right atrium into the right ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Fig: Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v= Positive wave x, x1, y= Negative waves

choices.text: Intracellular fluid
Extracellular fluid

questions.text: A body fluid sample is being studied and has Na: 10 mEq/L, K: 140 mEq/L, CI: 4 mE/L. Identify the compartment from which the sample has been obtained? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intracellular fluid

 

Explanation

 

The electrolyte composition in the sample obtained has high concentration of potassium, suggests that it is intracellular fluid (IC) compartment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial and Option C. Extracellular Fluid generally have higher sodium and chloride concentrations and much lower potassium concentrations.

 

Option D. Plasma, part of the extracellular fluid, would similarly show higher sodium and chloride but lower potassium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The composition of potassium, sodium, and chloride in the sample aligns with that typically found in intracellular fluid, reflecting its origin from within cells, where potassium is the major cation, unlike extracellular compartments dominated by sodium and chloride.

questions.text: The image below depicts which of the following types of cell-to-cells signaling? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Paracrine

 

Explanation

 

The given image shows the paracrine cell-to-cell signaling mechanism where signaling molecules released by a cell only affect nearby target cells.

 

An example of paracrine signaling is the release of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor released by the endothelial cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Autocrine: Incorrect. In autocrine signaling, a cell targets itself, releasing signals that bind to receptors on its own surface.

 

Option C. Endocrine: Incorrect. Endocrine signaling involves hormones that are released into the bloodstream and affect distant target cells.

 

Option D. Merocrine: Incorrect. Merocrine refers to a type of exocrine secretion where cells secrete substances via exocytosis; it is not a type of intercellular signaling but a mode of secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: A - Glucose, B - PAH, C - Bicarbonate and D - Inulin
A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH
A - PAH, B - Inulin, C - Glucose and D - Bicarbonate
A - Inulin, B - Glucose, C - Bicarbonate and D – PAH

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph given below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D – PAH

 

The correctly matched pair of substances and their renal clearance is option B.

 

 

The concentration of the substance changes as it passes through the tubules. Removing the substance from the filtrate is k/a tubular reabsorption and adding more of the substance to the filtrate is k/a tubular secretion.

 

Amount of the substance finally excreted = Amount Filtered + Secreted - Reabsorbed

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the renal handling of different substances such as PAH, inulin, bicarbonate, and glucose is crucial for assessing kidney function and diagnosing various renal disorders. Each substance's behavior in the nephron informs clinicians about different aspects of renal physiology, such as filtration rate and tubular function.
